subject: Re: [junit] testing for compile errors
msgSnippet: ... Sorry in advance if I am missing your point! It seems that you are trying to prove the java compiler works for both good and bad code that uses the
messageBody:
Jon Barrilleaux wrote:
> A while back I posted a question/suggestion about being able to test for
> compile-time erros. Such testing is especially important in the
> presence of java generics -- you want to be sure that some data types,
> such as in method parameters, compile correctly, but others result in a
> compile error. Testing these cases by hand defeats the whole purpose of
> unit testing.
Sorry in advance if I am missing your point! It seems that you are
trying to prove the java compiler works for both 'good' and 'bad' code
that uses the classes and methods you are interested in.

If this is the case, isn't it the job of the developer writing any new
code - which may use the existing classes - to make sure that their code
compiles and works?

If this isn't the case, can you illustrate the problem further? I
figure it must be more complex than capturing and checking the output
from javac?

--
Mark
